name: PSR J1719-1438
scenarioDescription:
The PSR J1719-1438 Exoplanetary System


Overview

PSR J1719-1438 is a star with 1.4 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.04 times its radius. It is located 3913.872 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 12.5 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

PSR J1719-1438 is known to have 1 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the PSR J1719-1438 system

PSR J1719-1438 b

PSR J1719-1438 b was discovered by the Parkes Observatory observatory using the Pulsar Timing method. The mass of PSR J1719-1438 b is 382.8 times the mass of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, PSR J1719-1438 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system. At more than 50 Earth masses, PSR J1719-1438 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system PSR J1719-1438, which contains 1 planets and was discovered by Parkes Observatory.
